qas.question: IBM created the software framework known as?

What company was Java supporting in 1998?

context: <b5_0>IBM<b5_0/> has been a leading proponent of the <b6_0>Open Source Initiative<b6_0/>, and began supporting <a0_0>Linux<a0_0/> in 1998. The company invests billions of dollars in services and software based on Linux through <a1_0>the <b9_0>IBM Linux Technology Center<b9_0/><a1_0/>, which includes over 300 Linux kernel developers. IBM has also released code <b8_0>under different open source licenses<b8_0/>, such as the platform-independent software framework <a2_0>Eclipse<a2_0/> (worth <b7_0>approximately US$40 million<b7_0/> at the time of the donation), the three-sentence International Components for Unicode (ICU) license, and the Java-based <a4_0>relational database management system<a4_0/> (RDBMS) Apache Derby. IBM's open source involvement has not been trouble-free, however (see <a3_0>SCO v. IBM<a3_0/>).
